byline.contributor: Roy Reed covered the civil rights movement for The New York Times in the 1960s and 1970s. Ashley Southall and Liam Stack contributed reporting.

abstract: Julian Bond, lifelong champion of equality who figured prominently in 1960s civil rights movement and later served notably as chairman of NAACP, dies at age 75; co-founded legal advocacy organization Southern Poverty Law Center and served 20 years in Georgia General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bond was also a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a former chairman of the N.A.A.C.P.

headline.main: Julian Bond, Charismatic Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 75
headline.print_headline: Julian Bond, Magnetic Leader of the Civil Rights Movement, Dies at 75

snippet: Mr. Bond was also a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a former chairman of the N.A.A.C.P.

keywords.value: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
keywords.name: organizations
